moneths established pope paying crownes absoluing house colonna censure restoring cardinal dignity whereunto condescended exceeding hardly howsoeuer truce concluded viceroy naples money disbursed borne bred vp yeeres conscience saluations sake sufficient keepe within selfe loue neighbour mooued trouble whole world vnnecessarily seeing without men liue god serued tranquillity hee added confusion gone farre remedie could deferred pope resolute applie calling councell learned men europe meeting together trueth shall bee cleered confusion vnquiet spirit place hath destinated citie taketh speciall notice person merit hee put minde example eneas siluius proposeth vnto example aentas siluius following owne opinion much slauery labour could get preferment canon trent beeing changed nature vehement fierce luther answere saying hee made account esteeme hee court rome whose hatred hee feared regarded good hee applied himselfe seruice god much hee could though vvhen done vvas diet preiudiciall apostolique sea offended hee saw hope lost authoritie reputation much diminished iudged necessarie shew sensible though side hee considered partie germany weakened counselled inward friend dissemble yet finally beeing assured declaring himselfe openly caesar hee straitly binde french king maintaine reputation hee resolued begin wordes take occasion passe deed coniunctures comport fifth august wrote great long letter emperor substance whereof hauing vnderstood decree made pope writeth long angry letter emperour spira duty fatherly charitie inforce tell opinion might follow example ely priest god seuerely punished much indulgence towards sonnes decree spira dangerous emperours soule extreamly troubled church hee violate rule obserued christian command cause religion bee referred church rome yet hee esteeming pope onely law god man hath power call councels decree spirituall matter willing thinke assembling generall nationall councell hath suffered idiot heretiques iudge religion hath made decree concerning sacred good restored honour rebel church condemned owne edict willing beleeue hee hath done thing owne inclination pernicious counsell beare ill church rome complaineth hath yeelded vnto scripture full example wrath god vsurpers office high priest vzza dathan abiron core king ozias others sufficient excuse say decree temporary vntill councel onely though thing done holy yet regard person belonging wicked god hath alwayes exalted prince haue beene deuoted sea rome head church constantine theodosij charles great contrarily hath punished haue giuen due respect vnto example hereof anastasius mauritius constan pilip leo others henry cause chastised owne sonne also fredericke prince onely whole nation haue beene punished iewes putting death christ sonne god grecian hauing many wayes contemned vicar thing ought feare descended emperours haue receiued honour church rome haue giuen commendeth desiring amendment church withall doth aduise leaue charge thereof god hath giuen emperour minister gouernour head added hee desired reformation hath declared often intimating councel whensoeuer sparke hope hath appeared might assembled though vaine vntill yet hee beene wanting duety desiring much councel remedy mischiefes well generall good christendome particular germany hath neede thereof hath beene intimated already though deferred vntill bee opened vntill returne end next moneth greater part bishop moued pouertie incommoditie made grieuous complaint raised sedition among themselues threatning would depart recourse francis castelalto resolued giue pope charge fortie ducat yeere bishop nobili bertinoro money giuen poore bishop chioza complained rest fearing munificence might giue pretence hereafter declared themselues subsidie hee changed opinion hee assembled clergie nobility chiefe men state yeere established another reformation though approoued many pleased whole clergie yea maior part opposed made groperus head giuen counsell promoted entreated archbishop desist expect generall councell least imperiall diet able obtaine yeere appealed pope emperour supreme aduocate protectour church archbishop published writing appeale friuolous hee could desist belonged glory god amendment church hee doe either lutheran others hee obserued doctrine agreeable holy scripture archbishop going reformation clergie collen insisting vpon contrary emperour receiued clergie protection cited archbishop hath beene said newes comming trent gaue matter passe time least discourse legate much mooued amongst prelate present vnderstanding blamed emperour making himselfe iudge faith reformation gentle word spake emperours proceeding scandalous began know esteemed bee idle scorned world therefore discourse constrayned withall latin church holdeth vulgar edition authenticall thus bee vnderstood concerning faith manner errour though small matter expression wordes may mistaking impossible word one language bee whole translation beget confusion article sense holy scripture doctrine cardinall caietan gaue occasion speake diuersly taught practised himselfe new conceit agree text discourse exposition scripture thing againe diuines father approoued opposed first seemed spirituall tyrannie forbid faithfull make vse proper ingenie according grace god hath giuen iust prohibition exercise talent giuen v god men ought bee inticed allurement reading holy writ pleasure nouitie bringeth shall bee remooued men euer abhorre strictnesse make men apply themselues study abandon consequence studie care pietie varietie spirituall gift belongeth perfection church found amongst father whose writing great diuersitie oftentimes contrarietie yet ioyned assured charitie libertie bee graunted age others haue inioyed spirituall fruit schoolemen though doctrine theologie haue dispute meaning scripture yet haue many difference point religion lesse dangerous better imitate antiquitie hath restrained exposition scripture left free contrarie opinion sayd popular licence worse tyrannie fit curbe vnbrideled wit otherwayes could hope see end present contention anciently allowed write vpon holy bookes neede regard exposition men time holy life setled minde confusion could bee feared therefore schoolemen seeing neede exposition church scripture onely sufficiently aboundantly declared tooke another course seale obligation name keepe himselfe obseruing commandements transgressed lost well others himselfe incurred punishment also deriued euery one transgression adam belonged euery one cause others vertue transgression adam imputed vnto paul saying haue sinned adam must bee vnderstood haue committed sinne alleadged example st paul hebrewes affirmeth leui paid tithe melchizedek hee paid great defend opinion saint thomas diuines obiections catarinus brought new exposition dominicus soro crosseth opinion catarinus said adam sinned actually eating forbidden fruit remained sinner habituall qualitie caused action euery bad action disposition bred minde actor though act past remaineth called sinner adam action transitory existence hee wrought habituall qualitie remaining passed posteritie transfused proper vnto euery one adam action originall sin consequent habit theologues call priuation righteousnesse may wel expounded cosidering man called sinner hee transgresseth actually also vntill sinne bee cancelled regard punishment consequence sinne regard preceding transgression selfe maketh man crooked vntill hee bee straightned againe said actuall action effect remaineth action past hee compared originall sinne crookednesse indeede spirituall obliquitie whole nature man adam hee made himselfe crooked transgressing precept whole nature man consequent euery particular person remained crooked curuitie adam owne hee truely crooked sinner vntill hee bee straightened grace god two opinion sharpely disputed euery one pretended owne receiued synode consideration originall sinne without baptisme vow thereof beginning iustification men age proceedeth preuenting grace inuiteth dispose themselues consenting cooperating freely doe willingly might refuse manner preparation first beleeue willingly diuine reuelations promise knowing one selfe bee sinner turne feare god iustice mercie hope pardon therefore begin loue hate sinne finally purposing bee baptized begin new life keepe commandements god iustification followeth preparation onely remission sinnes sanctification also hath cause finall glory god eternall life efficient god meritory christ instrumentall sacrament formall iustice giuen god receiued according good pleasure holy ghost according disposition receiuer receiuing together remission sinnes faith hope charitie saint paul saith man iustified faith gratis ought vnderstood faith beginning thing precede iustification meritorious grace sinnes pardoned vaunteth reposeth himselfe onely confidence certainty remission neither ought said onely faith doth iustifie sacrament power giue grace doeth resist seeing happeneth seldome grace obtained meanes surely little child many haue small vnderstanding saued way ordinary men haue weake disposition would suffice acutenesse pope differeth opinion others iudgement saw immediatly penetrate bottome iudged enterprise would bee good pernicious emperour maruelled much wisedome counsell great prince one victory hee thinke hee made iudge mankinde presuppose hee able contest party prince adhering one might oppresse another contend much boldnesse vanity hee foresaw doctrine would generally displease catholikes court protestant would impugned defended none wherein neede paine enemy would worke himselfe could doe better permit publication hinder rather state reformed may easily fall onely neede three thing emperour know put vpon businesse soone might first blow protestant effect first fit make light opposition thing second set foote interest germane prelate third make cunningly appeare doctrine doctrin sixt canon caused much speech christ hee breathed disciple gaue holy ghost saying whose sinnes remit remitted whose sinnes retaine retained institute sacrament enan e considered baptisme first christ instiruted eucharist giue thankes god generall deliuerance mankind memorie himselfe author thereof sprinkling blood howsoeuer like rite haue beene formerly vsed though end hath beene said yet scripture doth expresse singularity christ would introduce rite confesse sinnes particular exactly vse euer like seemed strange hee would bee vnderstood word must bee drawne vnioynted consequence yea many consequence farre fetcht done councell wondred institutio made word remitto forme remit thy sinnes rather iabsolue thee others added word sacrament absolution instituted forme absoluo te one absolued one must say vnresistable necessitie another instituted forme likewise ligo te cannot vnderstood authoritie loose binde founded vpon word christ absolutely alike doth require absolution pronouncing wordes absoluo te binding doth require pronouncing word ligo te reason execute christ hath said quorum retinueritis c quaecunqne ligaueritis c necessary say ligo te execute quorum remiseritis quaecunque solueritis necessary say absoluo te likewise doctrine inferred fifteeneth point censured critique saide christ word constitute priest iudges sinnes therefore necessarie confesse absolutely particular together circumstance alter kinde seeing doeth appeare word lord hath distinguished two sort sinnes one bee remitted retained whereby would bee necessarie know delinquent guiltie one onely doeth comprehend therefore word peccata generall onely vsed hee hath distinguished two sortes sinner saying quorum quorum one penitent vnto remission granted another obstinate vnto denyed therefore rather know state delinquent nature number sinnes concerning circumstance alter kinde said euery honest man may sweare good conscience holy apostle disciple skilfull thing celestiall regarding humane subtilties neuer knowe circumstance alter kinde perhaps aristotle made speculation worlde would haue knowen vntill yet made article faith necessary saluation approoued absoluo iudiciall word reputed good consequence priest doe absolue iudges appeared inconstancie condemne say naked ministerie pronounce plaine office iudge nothing pronounce innocent transgressor guiltie metaphore iudge doth beare priest make iust man delinquent ascribed prince may pard offender restore good name hee maketh wicked man iust like iudge doeth euer transgresse office hee pronounceth thing hee first findeth true amazed read poynt specificall singular confession sinnes circumstance prooued iudicature cannot bee executed without knowledge cause equitie obserued imposing punishment fault knowen onely general afterwards christ hath commanded confession may impose codigne punishment said plainely mock world think men fooles perswade themselues absurdity beleeued without doe knoweth seeth dayly confessor enioyne penance onely without weighing merit fault without hauing least consideration would seeme considering word councell confessor haue balance make difference euery graine yet oftentimes recite fiue pater nosters shall bee penance many murder adultery theft learned confessor generally giuing penance doe say euery man doe impose onely part penance therefore necessarie knowen king hee sent bishop viterbo instruction shew nationall sendeth nuncio spaine disswade councell kingdome would bee kinde schisme vniuersall church giue bad example nation make prelate proud assuming greater authoritie diminution owne generally knowen earnestly desire restitution pragmatique would first bring meanes king would lose whole collation regalities presentation bishoprickes abbies whence would follow prelats acknowledging power king would refuse obey yet inconueniences euils presse would prouided heretikes doe professe already esteeme prelate whatsoeuer doe would bee opposed protestant minister cause done true remedie make prelate curate reside keepe flockes opposing furie woolues proceed iustice iudged bee heretiques iudges faith cannot bee done regard multitude vse force armes compell performance duetie contagion doth increase thing beeing done difference might bee compleatly endded celebration generall councell hee would immediatly intimate king would resolue reduce contumacious obedience increase number strength hee promised assist power labour king spaine prince italie doe like hee would bee perswaded compell subiects force nuncio instruction propose vnto mischiefe troubleth france poyson infecteth kingdome neighbour place commeth geneua extirpation roote perswade ye king make ware geneua would take away great nourishment euill making warre kingdome hee euacuate bad humor trouble therefore exhor king ioyne good worke promising hee would ee king spaine duke sauoy doe like pope gaue bishop commission also negotiate thing duke sauoy passed wrote king spaine ealt nuncio would labour diuert cofin nationall councell would hurtfull france bad example spaine worse low countreys duke sauoy hearkened proposition warre geneua promising employ himselfe wholly two king would bee content assist warre bee made citie belonging dominion iust case wonne possesse himselfe therefore holinesse would come effect necessary make league plaine capitulation lest great inconuenience might arise either king agree himselfe bee abandoned prouoked suisse would vndoubtedly defend citie geneua king spaine considered france would permit bee hand frenchman good seruice regard vieinity franche countie therefore hee answered hee thought fit time make attempt nationall councell france perswaded would bee dangerous example state therefore hee dispatched away antonio di toledo prior lion signifie french king celebration councell would bee hurtfull regard diuision might arise kingdome infected hee prayed goe heerein king spaine disswadeth ye french king nationall synode sayd nothing mooued make request onely loue zeale glory god hee left consideration besides contention might cause within kingdome pernicious example prouinces would take preiudice would bring generall councell bee held onely remedy euils diuisions christendome would shew good intelligence betweene emperour bee would make protestant waxe proud preiudice publique cause hee added hee wanted force represse insolencies subiects hee would make vse force king spaine hee would willingly employ case owne person also neede subiects might boast brought indignitie whereof consider much beginning reigne hee gaue commission also ambassadour hee could obtaine hee reason negotiate suspension long time could treate cardinall lorayne hee vnderstood great hand councell prince church hauing great part gouernement kingdome hee bound consider dammage might redound christendome caused also request made duke guise constable queene mother marshall saint andrew hee gaue commission also aduise duchesse parma vargas ambassadour rome whatsoeuer hee likewise hee gaue pope aduice earnest request made one expresly sent need king assistance added necessitie himselfe turkes hauing taken yeere twenty gallies twenty fiue demandeth pope subsidie ecclesiastikes round ship fortresse gerbe forced increase armie therefore requested holinesse grant large subsidy church benefice kingdomes proposition assaulting geneua well taken france french men distasted proposition assaulting geneua would make hugonots reformatists called suspicious vnite themselues besides none going warre catholiques kingdome would bee left open opposite prouoke suisse protector citie seemed good regard seruice might doe crowne therefore answered nuncio onely thus great confusion afflict kingdome within impossible apply themselues matter abroad nationall french king answer concerning nationall synode councell answere giuen toledo nuncio king resolued keepe himselfe kingdome catholique vnion hee would make nationall councell separate himselfe vnite church went astray generall councell would please likelyhood profitable vrgent occasion would suffer expect time must needes long nationall presented rotchfort bee considered pope vnderstanding death king francis together aduice cardinall tornon queene ioyned nauar troubled minde fearing raines would giuen protestant therefore hee sent kingdome swarue true piety preiudice bee done councell intimated yeere ended thus leauing seedes whence greater trouble spring next yeere manriques came france deliuered ambassage hauing receiued well assured remoouing cause greater disease absence prelats hath beene cause corruption bee lesse deformation church haue resided pope hundred yeeres haue continually sate rome vsed diligence ancient prelats present haue continually resided church number one shew dioces better next haue continued without bishop say flocke without shepherd let consider bishop parish priest also haue cure soules mountaines hauing neuer seene bishop may paterne episcopall city zeale care father first councell bee commended imitated penalty haue incited prelats remaine owne church begun remooue receiued seeing hath christ wanteth nothing hee abundantly sufficient others sayd contrary illation neither necessary probable baptized filled christ st paul saith yet sacrament giuen vnto auoyded silence ceremony ended massebishop read doctrine doctrine read contained four head expressed foure head containing substance synod regard many error goe concerning sacrament eucharist hath determined expound belongeth communion sub vtraque child prohibiting faithfull beleeue teach preach otherwise therefore according iudgement custome church doth declare laickes clerkes doe say masse bound diuine precept communicate sub vtraque cannot doubted without preiudice faith communion vnder one kinde sufficient howsoeuer christ hath instituted giuen sacrament vnder two kindes cannot inferred hence obliged receiue speech lord related sixt chapter saint iohn although word name kind yet also name onely bread besides doth declare church hath euer power make mutation dispensation sacrament long substance remaineth may bee drawen generall wordes saint paul minister christ dispenser mystery god particularly eucharist concerning power reserued giue order word mouth church knowing authority howsoeuer vse kindes frequent beginning yet custome beeing changed iust cause hath approued communicate one onely man change without authoritie church doeth declare besides christ receiued vnder either kindes true sacrament hee receiueth one onely defrauded grace necessary saluation concerning fruit thereof finally doeth teach child vse reason bound sacramentall communion grace cannot bee lost age condemning antiquity contrary custome obserued place vndoubtedly beleeued haue done necessitie saluation probable cause conformitie doctrine foure anathematismes read shall say foure anathematismes read faithfull bound diuine precept necessitie saluation receiue kindes eucharist church hath iust cause communicate laickes clerkes doe celebrate masse kinde bread onely hath erred separate god hath ioyned meaning publique secret coniunction sacrament nothing ought affirmed without authoritie scripture tradition neither doe allow authoritie church yea tradition wee finde gregory pope many successor haue determined matrimonie cannot contracted betweene two vntill bee knowen degree kinred ioyned pope haue restrained vniuersalitie seuenth degree afterwards fourth generall dispensation diuorce iewes solemne vow doeth hinder de iure diuino pope authoritie camillus campeggius dominican friar agreeing others humane power extended sacrament added whosoeuer destroy essence matter also make vncapable sacrament man make water matter baptisme bread wheat bee matter eucharist hee shall destroy water turning ayre shall burne bread turning ash shall make matter bee capable forme sacrament matrimony ciuill nuptiall contract matter matrimoniall sacrament diuine institution beeing destroyed made force bee matter therefore cannot bee said church make nullity secret marriage would haue authority ouer sacrament true church nullifie secret nuptiall contract beeing voyd cannot receiue forme sacrament doctrine much please generality father plaine easie resolued difficulty antonius solisius spake contradict saying speculation true could bee applied purpose reason meant baptisme eucharist whosoeuer doeth destroy water bread doeth make vncapable formes annullation contract belongeth ciuill lawes secular magistrate therefore must take heede lest would giue authoritie church make voyd secret marriage bee rather giuen secular power amongst attributed power church disputed whether fit church vse two opinion one make voyd secret regard inconueniences ensue publique made without consent parent whose power made voyd also alleadged two reason one great inconueniences follow respect ruines happen family mariages vnaduisedly contracted yong men law god commanding obedience parent doeth include case principall law god doeth giue particular authoritie father giue daughter marriage plainely appeareth saint paul exodus example patriarch olde testament married father humane ciuill lawes haue esteemed marriage voide haue beene contracted without father againe saying bound god could bee loosed much troubled word saint paul granteth faithfull husband vnbeleeuing wife dwell remaine separated hee contented common exposition matrimonie vnbeleeuers insoluble alleadging insolubilitie law nature also word adam expounded saviovr vse church married vnbeleeuers haue beene baptized married againe matrimonie different faithfull refolued approue exposition caietan separation mentioned saint paul faithfull vnbeleeuer vnderstood matrimoniall bond thing worthy considered holy synod fornication sayd ought cause separation bond copulation cohabitation onely found himselfe much intangled hee said first diuorce might bee granted many respect many cause whereas gospel doth admit one fornication must needes vnderstood respect bond diuorce two respect may haue many cause hee gaue many exposition place gospel without approcuing disproouing concluded article ought condemned contrary made article faith apostolicall tradition howbeit word gospel plaine sufficient conuince lutheran concerning fourth article polygamic hee sayd law nature could bee permitted much infidel subiect christian hee said ancient father many wiues dispensation others dispensed god liue perpetuall sinne prohibition marriage certaine time briefly alleadged authoritie church disconuenience marriage time tooke occasion say man reason grieued bishop might dispence hee returned cause diuorce concluded world would complaine thing prelate vse authoritie wisedome charity cause euils doe reside giue gouernement vicar oftentimes without conuenient maintenance iustice ill administred grace well bestowed hee spake large residence saying declared bee de iure diuino impossible remooue abuse stoppe mouthes heretiques obseruing euill commeth bad execution lay blame vpon pope constitution therefore pope authoritie neuer defended well residence well established well executed without declaration de iure diuino notoriously erre thought preiudiciall authority pope whereas onely foundation vphold preserue hee concluded councell bound determine trueth spake efficacie willingly heard vltramontans displease papalins thought time impertinent touch matter gaue occasion party renew practises congregation twentieth february iohn ramirez franciscan friar hee spoken vpon article according common opinion diuines insolubilitie mariage sayd reason betweene man wife also betweene bishop church man ought depart wife ought bishop depart church spirituall bond lesse force corporall hee alleadged innocence third decreed bishop desire hee told matter chalice marriage priest vulgar tongue thing desired maiestie french king neither king spaine prince italie would euer consent matter reformation euery sort person would remaine present state reforme others whence commeth euery one demandeth reformation yet article thereof proposed doe oppose fauour euery one thinketh himselfe onely doth consider respect another euery one would haue pope minister designes thinking whether others remaine offended neither honest profitable fauour one disseruice another euery one would haue glory procure reformation yet perseuere abuse though without cause aforesayd doeth declare shall exceede space two moneths three whether continuate diuers time equity reason without dammage flocke must referred conscience prelats admonishing euery one absent sundayes aduent lent feast natiuitie resurrection pentecost corpus christi decree shall violate besides penalty imposed vpon nonresident vnder paul third mortall sinne may good onely restore ecclesiasticall discipline regarding binde themselues reforme ought obey though stiffenecked another think ought without admonition excommunicate anathematise king prince giuen god men absence cardinall loraine would neuer haue endured termes end dissolue councell hee attribute king belongeth hee inferred pope authority necessary vsing church good hee made french king like queene england nothing much offend hee said authority french king ouer person good ecclesiasticall founded vpon pragmatique concordates priuiledges giuen pope vpon law nature holy scripture ancient councels lawes christian emperours french ambassadours reprehended also follow step emperours spanish ambassador though interest made commotion knew reason de ferrieres defended himselfe said legate promised cardinall loraine matter bee spoken moderation touch affaire france performed king instruction beene imparted cardinall beene present would onely haue consented counselled protestation great ignorantes hauing seene nothing decretals lawes foure hundred yeeres thinke ecclesiasticall lawes would reforme king decretals would reforme decree lead also ancient time onely saint austine apostle also make french king queene england oppose haue begunne long since enlarge owne authority di ing king article much damnifie emperour catholique king doe france would neuer haue beene proposed therefore take example haue equall interest archbishop sant abbat claraual distasted went vp downe saying ambassadours done ill protest end make confusion giue occasion nationall councel france men regard perfectio consisteth vowes essentiall precept also regard common foode apparell none shal possesse good mooueable immooueable owne neither shall superiours grant immooueables much vse gouernement commenda vse ef mooueables shall neither superfluitie want synode granteth monastery though mendicant except capuchin minor obseruants possesse immoueable good command number religious monastery may bee established containe many maintained rent vsuall almes neither shall place bee built hereafter without licence bishop religious person shall goe seruice place person without leaue superiour depart conuent without command bishop shall haue care restore preserue enclosure nunnes exhorting prince commanding magistrate vpon paine excommunication assist nunnes shall goe monastery titulars shall bee created effect voyce absent supplied otherwise election shall voyde cloister nunnes superiour shall bee fortie yeeres age eight yeeres professed cannot bee thirtie yeeres age least fiue yeeres professed woman shall haue superioritie two nunries ouersee election shall stand without gate monastery immediatly vnder apostolique sea shall reduced congregation shal giue order gouernement superiours shall haue authoritie others haue haue beene formerly reduced congregation monastery nunnes subiect immediatly apostolique sea shall bee gouerned bishop delegate nunnes shall confesse communicate moneth least besides ordinarie confessor one extraordinary shall giuen twice thrice yeere shall keepe sacrament within monastery monastery haue cure soules secular men doe exercise shall subiect bishop farre concerneth ministerie sacrament except monasterie clugni abbats general head order doe reside abbats haue episcopall temporall iurisdiction regular shall publish obserue papall episcopall censure interdict also feast bishop shall command bishop shall bee iudge controuersies precedence betweene ecclesiasticall person whether secular regular appeale shall lie shall bee bound goe publique procession except liue strict inclosure regular resideth cloister committeth excesse abroad shall punished superiour bishop shall appoint also shall bee certified punishment otherwise delinquent may punished profession made age sixeteene yeeres compleat yeere probation shall voyde ronunciation obligation shall bee force except bee made within two moneths profession licence ordinarie time probation beeing ended superiours shall admit n profession send monastery meaning comprehend iesuites monasterie shall receiue thing nouice profession except foode apparell departure shall restored belongeth virgin shall receiue habit make profession except shee bee examined bishop well vnderstood shee hath condition required rule monasterie bee anathematized ambassadours england come councell pray sir doe englishman onely come councell selfe present councell take muster count poll see nation mett part except onely english haue mind wonder doe wonder neither three memorable patriarch constantinople antioch alexandria presbiter iohn grecian armenian persian egyptian more ethiopian indian come councell doe many people beleeue christ haue bishop baptized name christ bee christian called come ambassadours nation councell rather say pope call ecclesiasticall decree take hold wee wonder pope would afterwards call men councell hand hee condemned hereticks openly pronounced excommunicate without hearing either plea men bee first condemned punished afterwards brought triall absurd say cart horse would faine bee resolued whether pope meaning aduise councell concerning religion v account heretiques rather wee plead cause barre either change opinion presently hand bee condemned againe former without example denied heretofore iulius third side ridiculous hee thinke english come councell onely bee indited pleade themselues especially long since charged heynous crime onely side also owne england onely seeme thus stubborne bee
